docs.lead_paragraph: All the talk about medical errors in Washington these days leaves the impression that now that the problem is finally acknowledged, a solution is already in sight. Like an alcoholic at his first A.A. meeting, we have finally stood up and said the words out loud: bad errors happen in medical practice. There are drugs with look-alike labels and sound-alike names, there are nurses who mistake micrograms for milligrams and doctors who mistake left for right. The message seems to be that once systems like the ones safeguarding aviation and other high-risk industries are in place, medical care will become safe at last. Would that it were so. The truth is that unlike aviation or any other industry, medicine is a world etched in perilous shades of gray. Very little is black or white, right or wrong. Once systems are in place to fix stupid human mistakes, equally dreadful errors of judgment that are far harder to deflect will endure.

headline.main: The Healing Arts, Cast in Shades of Gray

docs.abstract: Abigail Zuger comments on problem of bad errors that happen in medical practice; points out that medicine, unlike aviation or any other industry, is a world etched in perilous shades of gray, where very little is black or white, right or wrong; guidelines on how patients and their families can guard against medical errors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Repeated checks of the nation's medical equipment have uncovered no serious prospect of Year 2000 computer failures, according to federal health officials and doctors responsible for safeguarding consumers. These doctors and officials say very few medical devices need to know the year. They add that there are plenty of prescription drugs, so consumers should not hoard.

headline.main: Medical Devices Do Well in Year 2000 Tests

docs.lead_paragraph: Two hundred years ago today, on Dec. 14, 1799, the first president of the United States died at the age of 67 in his bed at Mount Vernon. George Washington's doctors said the cause was ''inflammatory quinsy,'' a severe infection of the throat, but to this day controversy has surrounded his death. That debate -- did Washington die because of medical malpractice? -- is vividly evoked, though not resolved, in an article in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. The author, Dr. David Morens, an epidemiologist with the National Institutes of Health in Maryland, pulls together details about Washington's treatment from dozens of published medical and historical sources over nearly two centuries.

headline.main: Death of a President: A 200-Year-Old Malpractice Debate

docs.abstract: Controvery surrounding cause of Pres George Washington's death continues 200 years after and is is vivdly evoked in current issue of New England Journal of Medicine; Washington's doctors said he died of severe throat infection, but some say there was medical malpractice; lithograph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After a drunken driver left Margaret Kramer a young widow with four small children, her Minnesota friends and neighbors pitched in with ready-to-eat meals, took turns mowing the lawn and baby-sitting and a year or so later surprised her by painting the outside of her house while she and the children were away on vacation. When Frank Crewdson died, a friend said to his widow, Carole, ''Tell me what needs doing,'' then cleaned out her refrigerator, which had been neglected for the three months her husband had been ill. Other friends investigated cremation arrangements, brought frozen packets of homemade soup and took her shopping. When life quieted down a bit, friends took her out to lunch or to the movies and even on a short trip to the West Coast.

headline.main: Simple Acts Go a Long Way in Comforting the Bereaved

docs.abstract: Second of two columns by Jane E Brody on mourning and bereavement, and how to offer assistance and be of comfort to the bereaved (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago Rick Ellis of Bordentown, N.J., wanted to hire a personal trainer to build up what he called his ''98-pound-weakling body.'' But Mr. Ellis, a 47-year-old kindergarten teacher, was not about to go to the gym near his home and ask about one-on-one workouts. ''It was much too intimidating,'' he said. (It didn't help that the gym was called Powerhouse Fitness.) But once he tapped his reserves of self-esteem and got through the gym doors, he eased into personal training with a class called Be Fitt. The hourlong session, a hybrid of an exercise class and a one-on-one session, consisted of 6 to 10 clients working out on a circuit of free weights and machines with three trainers.
docs.abstract: Growing number of fitness trainers around country are offering benefits of one-on-one fitness to small groups of people who would prefer to sweat together; trainers at these health clubs offer instruction in hybrid sessions combining features of group exercise class and personal training; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A highly contagious respiratory virus that often overwhelms pediatric clinics in winter has arrived in force, federal officials say, and is sending twice as many babies to the hospital as scientists had expected. As a result, specialists are urging parents and pediatricians to be especially vigilant for breathing difficulties in babies at risk for the virus: twins and other multiples, whose lungs are generally not as developed at birth as single babies; premature babies; and those born with lung or heart disorders.
